Situation1: A serious situation has come up in the family, and the grandmother's presence is needed.
Expectation2: Diagnose patient illnesses accurately based on symptoms and tests
Situation2: A patient with symptoms of the common cold has come in for a routine check-up.
Story: I sat in my office, white coat buttoned, stethoscope around my neck, reviewing the chart of my next patient—a middle-aged man with a runny nose and a cough. It was a routine check-up, nothing urgent, but I knew I owed him my full attention. Just as I was about to call him in, my phone buzzed. It was my daughter, her voice trembling. “Mom, can you come? Grandma’s not well, and the kids are scared. We need you.” My heart clenched. As a grandparent, I was expected to be there, to comfort, to guide, to hold my family together in moments like this. But as a doctor, I had a duty to my patient, to listen carefully, to diagnose accurately, to not let my mind wander. The weight of both worlds pressed on me, each demanding my presence, each expecting me to put them first. I stared at the door, torn, my mind racing, feeling the impossible pull of love and responsibility.
